message.content: This question requires knowledge about the properties of materials and the phenomenon of refraction. Refraction occurs when light passes from one medium to another with a different refractive index. Objects made of melted sand, also known as glass, cause refraction of light because of the way light interacts with the molecules in the glass. Option (A) is incorrect because wind, being a flow of air, does not have the necessary properties to cause refraction. Option (B) is incorrect because wood does not have the same molecular structure as glass, so it does not cause significant refraction. Option (D) is incorrect because soil, like wood, does not have the necessary properties for refraction to occur.

This question requires knowledge of the properties of different materials and how they interact with light. When light passes through a medium with a different refractive index, such as melted sand, it bends or refracts. This causes the light to change direction as it passes from one medium to another. Option (A) is incorrect because wind does not have the properties necessary to cause refraction. Option (B) is incorrect because wood is not transparent and does not allow light to pass through it. Option (D) is also incorrect because soil does not have the necessary properties to cause refraction.

This question requires knowledge about the optical properties of materials. When light passes through different materials, it can change direction, or refract. The object that causes refraction of light is melted sand, also known as glass. Option (A) is incorrect because wind is a form of airflow and does not have physical properties that cause light refraction. Option (B) is incorrect because wood is a solid material and does not cause light refraction. Option (D) is incorrect because soil is also a solid material and does not cause light refraction.

This question requires a basic understanding of the properties of materials and their interaction with light. Refraction is the bending of light as it passes from one medium to another with a different optical density. In this case, objects made of melted sand (option C) cause refraction of light. When sand is melted and turned into glass, it becomes transparent and can refract light. Options A, B, and D are not related to the refraction of light. Wind (option A) is the movement of air and does not have a physical composition that can cause refraction. Wood (option B) is an opaque material that does not allow light to pass through, so it cannot cause refraction. Soil (option D) is a mixture of minerals and organic matter, but it also does not have the properties to cause refraction of light.

This question requires basic knowledge of the properties of materials and how they interact with light. When light passes through a material with a different optical density, it changes direction, which is called refraction. Objects made of melted sand, also known as glass, cause refraction of light. Option (A) is incorrect because wind does not cause refraction. Option (B) is incorrect because wood does not have the same properties as glass to cause refraction. Option (D) is incorrect because soil is not transparent and does not allow light to pass through for refraction to occur.

Option (A) is incorrect because wind does not cause refraction of light. Option (B) is incorrect because wood does not have the properties to cause refraction. Option (D) is incorrect because soil also does not have the properties to cause refraction.

Options (A), (B), and (D) are incorrect because they do not cause refraction of light. Wind is the movement of air and does not interact with light. Wood and soil do not have the same properties as glass that allow for refraction.
